summary: This document is a compilation of media articles and social media posts about Ghislaine Maxwell from July 2019 to March 2020. It includes headlines and excerpts from major publications like The New York Times, New York Post, Washington Post, and Vanity Fair, as well as social media threats and a report of a bounty offered for information on her whereabouts. The document illustrates the intense media scrutiny and public hostility directed at Maxwell following Jeffrey Epstein's arrest and death.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.role: Accused enabler and associate of Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central subject of all media articles and social media threats; described as Epstein's 'Lady of the House,' an alleged 'slave recruiter,' and a target of public outrage and bounty offers.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referenced as the central figure in the case, with Maxwell described as his long-entangled associate and alleged enabler; noted as deceased.

connections.description: Described as 'long entangled' and as Epstein's 'pal'; Maxwell is portrayed in media as his alleged enabler and 'slave recruiter'.

events.title: NY Times profiles Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: The New York Times publishes an article titled "The 'Lady of the House' Who Was Long Entangled With Jeffrey Epstein," marking her emergence as a major media target.

events.title: Media outlets label Maxwell as 'slave recruiter'
events.description: The New York Post and Washington Post publish articles accusing Maxwell of being part of Epstein's 'gang' of 'accused slave recruiters' and an 'enabler.'

events.title: Vanity Fair article on Maxwell
events.description: Vanity Fair publishes a piece on Ghislaine Maxwell, calling her 'America's Most Wanted Woman' and discussing the pronunciation of her name.

events.title: Bounty offered for Maxwell
events.description: The Sun newspaper offers a £10,000 reward for information on the whereabouts of Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Maxwell sues Epstein's estate
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell sues Jeffrey Epstein's estate, citing death threats and extensive legal fees.

keyFacts: Following Epstein's arrest and death in 2019, Ghislaine Maxwell became a primary focus of media scrutiny, portrayed as his chief enabler and alleged 'slave recruiter.'
A £10,000 bounty was publicly offered by The Sun newspaper in November 2019 for information leading to Ghislaine Maxwell.
Maxwell faced intense and violent threats on social media, including calls for her death, from July 2019 onward.
In March 2020, Ghislaine Maxwell sued Jeffrey Epstein's estate, citing death threats and high legal costs as reasons.
The document catalogs the shift in public and media narrative that positioned Maxwell as 'Person #1' in the Epstein case after his death.
